properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwesterly winds will gust between 60 and 70 km/h Thursday afternoon. These strong winds combined with the snow will give widespread blowing snow creating low to nil visibilities locally. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:

The snow and strong winds will generate blowing snow causing reduced to zero visibilities locally through Thursday evening. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON (March 3, 2021 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Vernon because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath,cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-04T09:15:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-03T17:16:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2123476770.2021
Area: North Okanagan
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of snow squalls, with intense snowfall rates, strong winds and blowing snow. Total snowfall: locally 5 cm or more in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h. Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity. Time span: continuing this evening. Remarks: Flurries mixed with snowsqualls may continue into this evening with cold westerly winds. Occasional flurries and blowing snow will likely persist through tonight and Thursday. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-04T05:29:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-03T19:17:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1240886338.2021
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Wind chill values near minus 40 are expected overnight Wednesday. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. properties.Summary:

Remarks: Persistent light to moderate snow, strong north to northwesterly winds, and cold temperatures will combine to give frequent extended periods of reduced visibilities in blowing and drifting snow. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Southerly winds gusting between 50 and 60 km/h combined with temperatures in the mid minus thirties will produce extreme wind chill values of minus 50 or lower this evening. As temperatures approach minus forty and winds abate to 10 to 15 km/h after midnight, similar values can be expected overnight. These values will likely persist into Thursday morning before moderating ever so slightly Thursday afternoon as winds completely diminish to calm. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-04T12:39:26-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts of nearly 30 centimetres are expected from Thursday morning through Friday morning. The snow will fall rapidly during the day Thursday and will then taper Thursday evening. Southerly winds of up to 70 kilometres per hour Thursday could produce some blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally upto 15 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: Avalon peninsula. Time span: continuing this afternoon. Remarks: A snow squall has developed from Point Lance to Ferryland and is expected to meander to the north through the afternoon. The squall may reach the metro area this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-04T05:45:47-00:00
